The initial police contingent consisted of 74 Australian Federal Police, Australian Protective Service personnel and members of the New Zealand Police. Immediately upon arrival, community policing patrols commenced in Honiara with the Royal Solomon Islands Police. I have spoken to Acting Commissioner Ben McDevitt, who has told me that those patrols were warmly received by both the local police and the community. These resources have been increased to the level of 103 police personnel, and we are also looking to a contribution from the Pacific in relation to this. Acting Police Commissioner Ben McDevitt was sworn in as Deputy Police Commissioner of the Royal Solomon Islands Police and yesterday was made Acting Police Commissioner for a month while the commissioner is away on leave. That demonstrates the great cooperation and trust that exists between the Solomon Islands and the Australian Federal Police.

answer.para: A weapons amnesty has been announced for the community as well as a direction to the Royal Solomon Islands Police to surrender all weaponry previously taken or removed from the police armoury. I am pleased to report that, as of Sunday night, a total of 962 weapons had been surrendered. Of these, 793 were military style weapons and 47 were Royal Solomon Islands Police weapons. The amnesty will conclude on 21 August this year and after that date any person found in possession of a firearm will be prosecuted.

Planning is well advanced to commence investigations into significant and outstanding crimes. Police outposts have been established at Avu Avu on the Weathercoast and at Auki, on Malaita. Both have received favourable support from the communities there. We are also setting about establishing new discipline and professional standards for the local police. On 8 August this year, special coordinator Nick Warner and Acting Police Commissioner Ben McDevitt met with Weathercoast militant Harold Keke. Discussions are ongoing in relation to matters dealing with him, and the government regards these as serious matters that need to be resolved.

By early September we anticipate that the participating police force will amount to some 300 personnel. This will enable those people in the islands to carry out the mission we have given them. We look forward to a successful resolution of this mission and a return of all safely home. What we are doing firstly, though, is to install law and order and to make sure that the president, ministers and key facilities are protected. Of course, we have a longer term objective, and that is to enhance infrastructure in the Solomon Islands and to provide professional development and training to the Royal Solomon Islands Police. That will take more time and we realise that this involvement by the Australian Federal Police will not be a short one. It is not without its dangers, and we realise that, but the Australian Federal Police, Australian military personnel and the Australian Protective Service are doing a great job not only for the security of the Pacific region but also for the security of Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Alston, representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Is the minister aware that a letter from the Secretary to the Department of Education, Science and Training was tabled in the parliament yesterday by the minister for education? Can the minister confirm that this letter, which purports to provide an accurate account of the censorship of the National report on higher education 2001, claims that the minister for education was not formally briefed on the report at any time prior to 23 July 2003? How does this assertion possibly fit with evidence from departmental officers given to the Senate estimates hearings on 5 June 2003 that what was described by the secretary as the final draft version of this report had been sent to the minister in the first quarter of the year?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I can only take the assertions of the secretary at face value—
—Weren't you at estimates?
—If Senator Carr has a photographic recollection of what was said at estimates, he is a better man than I am.
—It is in the Hansard; read the Hansard!

—Can I suggest that, if you think that someone who has asked a question without notice should be able to instantly read the Hansard, you are a lot further advanced in terms of technology then we are. We actually have to go back and look at the record—either read the Hansard online or in hard copy. We cannot just conjure it up, unfortunately. I envy your psychic skills; if you are able to do that then that is a magnificent achievement. But, unfortunately, in order to assess that statement against what was said in the estimates committee, one would obviously have to go back and check the record and make sure that they were talking about the same subject matter and generally explore the proposition. All I can do is reiterate what is contained in the letter, of which I do have a copy: that Minister Nelson was not formally briefed on the report by the department at any time before July 2003. One is entitled to assume that, as this letter was written and signed yesterday, it takes into account what was said at the estimates committee at an earlier point in time.

—Mr President, I rise to ask a supplementary question. I ask: can the minister also confirm that, contrary to the secretary's claim in the letter, editing began on that report in April 2002; that the consultants Ray Adams and Associates had been commissioned for this work in June 2001; and that formatting, indexing and other final preparations for publication had been completed by April 2002? Who is to be believed on these matters—the departmental officers who gave evidence before a parliamentary committee or a minister desperately trying to cover up his own incompetence?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am sure that it is not the latter, Mr President. Once again, one cannot simply conjure up what might have been provided by Senator Forshaw by way of information about who did what back in 2001. What I can say, from the letter from the secretary, is that, in November 2002 or thereabouts, the department took the decision to remove material regarding HECS that had recently become the subject of media reporting. The decision was made because of the department's concerns in relation to the methodological difficulties inherent in analysis of this kind and the incompleteness and inconclusiveness of some of the findings, which meant that it did not have a valid place in the report. If you do not agree with that logic then I would be very interested to hear your contrary approach. In other words, if you accept that there were methodological difficulties which did not convey a true and accurate picture then I would not have thought that you would be suggesting that they should have been left in the report. It is the obligation, one presumes, to get it right— and that is what was done on this occasion. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Revenue. On 22 July the Treasurer released an exposure draft of the Charities Bill defining `charity' for all Commonwealth legislation—a bill which is of serious concern to the charitable sector, given this government's form in cold-shouldering charities which disagree with it. Can the minister confirm whether a second bill containing so-called consequential amendments has been or is being drafted? If so, can the minister assure the Senate that any such bill will also be released for public consultation with charities under the auspices of the Board of Taxation, alongside the Charities Bill?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Cherry, for the question. The consequential amendments to the Charities Bill have not been released, but of course they do deal with a number of technical matters—the technical interaction of the exposure draft and the current law—so there is no substantive policy contained in the consequential bill, as you would appreciate. Senator Cherry's question is premised on a completely false statement; namely, that this government has cold-shouldered charities. That is an extraordinary notion when what has in fact been released is an exposure draft of the Charities Bill 2003. The exposure draft is in the public domain for the very purpose of public consultation—for the board to conduct consultations—and it is certainly not in any way a rebuff to charities.

answer.para: In fact, we announced the policy in August 2002, which is 11 months ago, and draft legislation has been released recently. The draft provides—as, indeed, is the current situation—that a charity must be not-for-profit, have a dominant purpose or purposes that are charitable and be for the public benefit. The definition follows the definition that has been in operation, in effect, for more than 400 years of common-law precedent. The draft legislation only widens the definition of `charity' to include not-for-profit child care available to the public, self-help bodies that have open and non-discriminatory membership, and closed or contemplative religious orders that offer prayerful intervention for the public.

I hope that there will be some people offering prayerful intervention for the Democrats, because nothing could be further from the truth but that this government not only understands the needs of charities but also has, in the move to the new tax system, specifically adjusted the tax law so that charities can effectively operate. In fact, the definitions that are now in the exposure draft simply take up what has always been the case. So recent criticism—I think Senator Cherry made some criticisms of the exposure draft—really has no foundation when you look at the draft and the words. The most important point of all is that this is, as it says, an exposure draft. The Board of Taxation will now have an opportunity—as will stakeholders, members of the public and anyone interested—to have some input into its final shape.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I rise to ask a supplementary question. The minister mentioned in her answer the response of the government to the Charities Definition Inquiry report made 11 months ago. We have been very contemplative about that response as well. Two years ago the report described the key charitable definition of `public benevolent institution' as clearly out of date, and recommended a broader category of benevolent charity to extend concessions to charities with the dominant purpose of benefiting, directly or indirectly, those whose disadvantage prevents them from meeting their needs. When will the government respond to that recommendation of the report, made over two years ago, that the definition of `benevolent charity' be updated after 80 years? Will that be in the consequential amendments bill?

talker.name: Coonan, Sen Helen
Senator COONAN
talker.role: Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —As I have said, the consequential amendments bill deals with technical matters, but the exposure draft that is currently on the table codifies the common law definition of charities and reinforces the dominant purpose—that a charity must be not for profit, must have a dominant purpose or purposes that are charitable and must be for the public benefit. They are pretty time-honoured concepts. They have endured for over 400 years. They are now in an exposure draft and they are going to the Board of Taxation for consultation. It will be a matter obviously that will need to take final shape when all of the consultations have had an opportunity to be considered.

subdebateinfo.title: Education, Science and Training: Branch Restructure

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to Senator Alston, representing the Minister for Education, Science and Training. Can the minister confirm that, following production of research in preparation for the 2001 national report, some of which was deemed to be politically sensitive, the then departmental head, Dr Shergold, undertook a restructure of the Education Information and Analysis Branch of the Department of Education, Science and Training? Can the minister confirm that at that time two-thirds of the uncommitted funds for the branch were cut? Can the minister also confirm that many former officers of the EIA Branch who worked on the subsequently doctored reports are no longer working in the Research, Analysis and Evaluation group? Has this branch been gutted of funding and staff as punishment for not following the correct political line as stipulated by the Howard government?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —One gets a fascinating insight into how those who were unfortunate enough to have been students when Senator Carr was a teacher must have been indoctrinated. He uses all those nice, impartial, objective statements like `gutted', `deemed to be politically sensitive', `doctored' and whatever other extremely pejorative terms he can. That is basically what Senator Carr's modus operandi is. Senator Carr asked about the Research and Evaluation Branch of the department. Work undertaken in the former Research and Evaluation Branch is now performed—
—Former?
—Former, yes.
—Gutted.

—So former equals gutted? I will be interested to see this new Labor dictionary when it comes out. It must be a very entertaining piece of work. It will have very little to do with reality, but I am sure it will keep you amused in opposition for a long time to come.
—Order! Senator Sherry, shouting across the table is not only out of order, but it also may affect the cough that you have had recently. I think you should be careful.
—I should say in passing that, when Senator Carr uses the term `deemed to be politically sensitive', he does not of course explain who by, so one presumes that it is deemed by Senator Carr.

answer.para: In terms of the work undertaken in the former Research and Evaluation Branch, that work is now performed in the larger Research, Analysis and Evaluation Group. This group was formed in the first half of 2002 and consolidates, expands and strengthens work that was going on in several areas of the department before its formation. The formation of this group recognises the central role of research, analysis and evaluation in underpinning the department's policy and program work. The formation of that group allowed some modest savings to be made to resourcing levels. It retains, however, a strong research, analytical and evaluation capacity. It is a shame Senator Carr does not have the same.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the research priorities of the new information and analysis group have been changed to concentrate on short-term polling research? Can the minister also confirm that the public servants have been ordered to undertake telephone polling on community and parental attitudes to schooling? Is this the type of research that the government finds politically palatable? Does the government condone the use of public servants to work the banks of telephones for this purpose? Was Mark Textor involved in this polling, in the preparation of the polling questions or in any other capacity?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You would have to strongly suspect he just threw that Textor question in, because his basic proposition was, `Isn't it wrong for public servants to be asked to conduct community research or polling?' and then he just threw in the Textor question. That is pretty typical. As Senator Hill quite rightly said, Max Moore-Wilton was targeted for a purpose, and Mark Textor is being targeted for the same purpose—that is, to send a warning shot to anyone in the community who might be prepared to work for the government that that mob over there have long memories. They will have to have elephantine memories. By the time they ever get to government, they will have forgotten who they were targeting. If Senator Carr's objection is that community research should not be undertaken, I would like to hear about it, because I would have thought it is quite important. We know that your agenda is only `Did the trades hall tick off on it? Did the faction give it the nod?' We actually think it is more important to find out what the community thinks. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Health and Ageing. Would the minister please inform the Senate as to progress on what action the government is taking to guarantee that consumers can determine whether a pharmaceutical or drug has been created, tested or manufactured utilising embryonic stem cells or human embryos? Isn't it true that consumers do have the right to know of the use of these ethically controversial procedures and to have an informed conscientious choice as to whether they receive that application or not?

—When we debated the Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2003, I did undertake to refer Senator Harradine's proposed amendment to the Therapeutic Goods Administration for urgent consideration and advice and to include an analysis of the regulatory options available to meet Senator Harradine's proposal. The Senate will recall, I am sure, that Senator Harradine foreshadowed and proposed the following amendment: `Where a person uses human embryos or human embryonic stem cells in or in the testing, creation or manufacture of any therapeutic good, a statement that the product has been tested, created or manufactured using human embryos must be included in the prescribed information or material that is included with the therapeutic good.'

answer.para: I understood what Senator Harradine wanted to do and I did indicate that I thought it was appropriate, if possible, that people ought to know. I said that if people felt so strongly about therapeutic outcomes from products derived from embryonic stem cells and they were morally opposed to it, they should have the opportunity to demonstrate that by not accepting treatment. So I understood why Senator Harradine was asking for this. The TGA undertook detailed consultations with the pharmaceutical industry to assess the feasibility and practicality of Senator Harradine's proposed amendments and the regulatory options available.

A final draft of the report was given to Senator Harradine in mid-June—in accordance with my undertaking to the Senate that the TGA would report back within month— and there have been ongoing discussions between Senator Harradine and the government. These have focused on examining the best way forward to meet the spirit of Senator Harradine's amendments and the need to define the exact nature of any regulatory changes, to ensure that Australia does not miss out on breakthrough products that hold the potential for significant medical and treatment advances because of requirements that prove impractical for the pharmaceutical industry to meet. Given that Australia represents only one per cent of the world pharmaceutical market, it is important that any regulation change supported by the government does not put at risk any access to such breakthroughs. However, where information is available, the government would consider changes that would be helpful to consumers and health professionals in making informed choices about the clinical options that are available.

There has been considerable agreement that the pharmaceutical companies should be able to provide advice as to what materials have been involved in the manufacture of medicines. However, the provision of advice for materials that might have been used in the testing and creation of these products is much more difficult to determine. Pharmaceutical products can take more than 20 years to find their way to market and their final marketing indications may be quite different to those envisaged at the time of their development. Careful consideration needs to be given to where the pharmaceutical companies would have easy access to records which would enable them to give undertakings in regard to materials that may have been used at any point in the testing of such products. That is the issue that we are finding the most difficult to deal with. When the regulatory options have been fully explored, a final report will be tabled in the Senate. I intend to do this at the earliest possible opportunity.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Despite the understanding that I had with the government at the highest level, I believe that this matter has not been advanced in any shape or form. I have also had discussions with the opposition. As I understand it, there is cross-party concern that, irrespective of the ethics of the matter, this is also an issue of consumers' right to know. What I want to know is: are you going to kowtow to the drug companies or are you going to give the consumers that right to know? What you have just said to the chamber is no advance whatsoever on what the case was two months ago. What action are you taking right now?

—I have indicated what action I am taking. I have in good spirit tried to address the issue that Senator Harradine has raised. I understood what he was saying in that debate. I find it a little churlish of him to say that I am kowtowing to the drug companies, because I do not believe that that is the case. It is not the case. It is quite difficult to regulate, particularly looking at products that are used in the development of a drug and to go back through maybe 20 years of research—or further back—to find out what material has been used.

—Senator Harradine had his chance to ask a question. He might like to move that the Senate take note of the answer after question time. I believe that we are moving forward as well as we can. This is a very difficult issue. We should not infringe on the rights of those people who wish to use a product that is derived from embryo stem cell research if the regulations are so onerous that we cannot import, develop or use those medications. We have to deal with this in a way that informs the public appropriately and that does not infringe on anybody's rights. (Time expired)

— My question is also directed to Senator Patterson in her capacity as Minister for Health and Ageing. Can the minister explain to the Senate why the government is spending more than $25 million of taxpayers' money on a PBS advertising campaign telling people to use fewer drugs. Given that pharmaceutical company marketing campaigns and doctors' prescribing habits largely drive PBS usage, would the money not be better spent on practical measures aimed at reducing excessive or inappropriate prescribing?

—I thank Senator Evans for the question. It is wonderful to have a dorothy dixer from the other side of the chamber. Let me start by saying that over the last couple of months we have added mabthera for non-Hodgkin's lymphoma to the PBS. We have had gleevec for treatment of the earliest stages of chronic myeloid leukaemia on the PBS, and we have put enbrel on the PBS. Those three medications alone will cost—and listen very carefully on the other side—$700 million over four years. Those three medications that have been added in the last few months will consume nearly 70 per cent of the modest increase that we have had in this chamber for over a year and a half—since the budget before last. Seven hundred million dollars for those medications! At some point crunch time will come. There are more medications of that order lining up.

answer.para: When I first became health minister we did some fieldwork. We found that people thought that an expensive medication was around $20 and that people paying the non-concessional fee thought they were cross-subsidising people on a health care card. That is far from the truth. The most commonly prescribed medication on the PBS costs $80 per person per month—about $80 depending on the strength and the brand that they have. Some medications—and gleevec is one of them—cost about $6,600 a month. If you are on a health care card, you get it for $3.70; if you are not, you get it for $23.10, depending on whether you have reached the safety net. If you have reached the safety net, you get it for nothing—if you are on a health care card. If you are not on a health care card, you get it for to $3.70. People did not understand that. The cost of the PBS has gone from $1 billion in 1991 to over $5 billion, we think, in this financial year.

We predict that it could go to about $7 billion in 2006. This is unsustainable growth. It is the fastest growing part of the health bill. We have a range of measures that have been put in place to curb the PBS, including getting prescribers to prescribe differently, including working with the pharmaceutical industry, including working with patients, including working with divisions of general practice to improve the use of medicines—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order on the question of relevance, Mr President. I asked a question about the costs of the advertising campaign, its objectives and why it was not better directed. The minister is giving an explanation—which I have heard on many occasions—about the costs of the PBS, but it is not the question she was asked. If she wants to get a dorothy dixer on that, by all means, but the question was about the cost of the electronic advertising campaign and why it was directed at consumers.
—The minister has another minute and a half remaining of her answer. I am sure she will get to the point.

—The Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is not understood by Australians. We put the true price of the medication on the label. Many of you will have had people say, `I can't believe that this medication costs $200; I can't believe it costs $40.' I had an email from a pharmacist the other day saying that somebody came and asked them to go out to their car and they brought in boxes full of medication which added up to over $3½ thousand. They had seen the ads and thought that they should not hoard this medication. It was all out of date. It had been prescribed appropriately and had been dispensed with the right number of days between repeats et cetera.
—What if they were ill?

—The person was just keeping them. Senator Sherry over there has just stupidly said the person was really sick. They were so sick they had not taken $3½ thousand worth of medicine. What a stupid comment—the sort of comment you would expect from somebody on the other side who has got no understanding of the system that is breaking under the strain.
—Minister, ignore the interjections and address your remarks through the chair. And, Senator Sherry, please stop interjecting across the chamber.

—So we have a program to inform people not only about the cost of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme but about taking their medications more appropriately. It is not always about asking their doctor for medication; it is about doing something about their own health by losing weight, by going on a diet and by doing things where they can achieve sometimes better outcomes than by taking medications.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would appreciate it if the minister would address the original question in her second go at answering it. I think a lot of people are concerned that it is just a cynical campaign to soften up people for drug price rises rather than aimed at changing people's behaviour. Can the minister tell the Senate what the objective of the campaign is? What are the measures that she has put in place to measure the success or otherwise of the campaign and what independent assessment of the success or otherwise of the campaign will be made? How will that be made available to the public? What are the tests against which this $25 million of taxpayers' money being spent will be measured?

—As I indicated, this is an overall program as part of my plan to make sure that the PBS is sustainable into the future so that the next generation does not pay for our bills and to inform the Australian public. Research showed that the Australian public did not understand the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. They did not understand the rate at which medications are subsidised—about $5 for every $1 that a patient pays. They did not understand that there were medications that could cost up to $6½ thousand per person per month. They were wasting and hoarding those medications. There will be an evaluation of the campaign, including the materials that are being given to doctors and pharmacists to give to patients to tell them that the PBS is a precious gift from the taxpayer of Australia which needs to be preserved, protected and used wisely. But the people on the other side do not seem to care and demonstrate that fact by the stupid comment that we had in the middle of this debate. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Vanstone. Would the minister inform the Senate about the government's continued support for carers of children with disabilities?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I repeated in this place what I had said earlier last week—namely, that we would not remove the group of parents of children that were being reviewed, whose cases had been saved for five years, from receiving carer payments on the basis of a medical condition until we had an opportunity to have a look to see if there was a better way to do this. I also indicated yesterday that we already have in train a review of the recognised list of disabilities, and that will of course go ahead. However, we have decided, on the basis of material provided by the review of the 70,000 or so cases that have been saved and have not been looked at for five years, that there are some disabilities that we can, should and will add to the list of recognised disabilities. We will be adding Down syndrome, cystic fibrosis, uncontrolled epilepsy, moderate haemophilia, phenylketonuria and fragile X to the list of recognised disabilities. Of course, there are other disabilities that might not be specifically mentioned as disabilities in themselves, but if those people who have a close interest in this area go to the list of recognised disabilities they will see that there is a number of opportunities for people who are so affected to be considered as having a recognised disability because of severe physical or neurological disability as a consequence of that condition.

answer.para: With over 40 per cent of the cases that were saved since 1998 now reviewed, a high proportion of children with those disabilities are passing the test and being reinstated. As I indicated yesterday, my advice is that no carer of a child with Down syndrome had, under the review, lost their payment as a consequence of the medical condition. Some may have because the child is no longer in care or for some other reason, but not in relation to the medical condition. We will also be ensuring that in the list of recognised disabilities not only are the recognised disabilities themselves looked at—and the intention is that this review will be completed by Christmas—but also the formal definitions are looked at and, in particular, I am thinking of the formal definitions of visual impairment or severe or multiple disabilities.

I raised an example yesterday of a form where a doctor did not tick a box for bilateral blindness. The doctor may well believe he had a good reason not to tick the box. These are very technical areas that relate to the level of visual acuity, the range of vision and other matters. In any event, on review the person has been restored to payment. I have not named the doctor, but I make the point that the doctor may well have good reason for believing he did the right thing. He may equally agree, having had discussions with the department—

talk.start.para: —I suspect he has contacted your office in relation to this.
—No-one has contacted my office in relation to this matter.
—No-one has contacted your office?
—No. Sorry; you were hoping for a score, and you have just missed out there.
—The minister will address her remarks through the chair and ignore the interjections.
—You are in here apologising, so something has happened.

—There are a couple of other things I would like to say on this matter. The opposition raise the question of apologies. I was asked yesterday by Senator Collins to explain how this woman had been cut off if the review had been put on hold. (Time expired).

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that there has been so much misrepresentation on this particular issue and scaremongering by the Labor Party that people are going to be taken off the list, I ask the minister whether she has any further material that she would like to enlighten the Senate with.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I warmly thank Senator Knowles for that supplementary question. Of course, Senator Collins had not checked her facts. In fact, the person whom she named was removed from payment before I announced that the review had been put on hold. Anyone who heard the question yesterday would have thought that, despite having said that Centrelink would not cut off people who have medical conditions, nonetheless this person had been cut off. Senator Collins actually said:

quote.para: Given that the minister's office told the ABC's PM program that `Centrelink won't make any decision to cancel payments on medical grounds until the government has examined the review process,' who on earth made the decision ...

answer.para: There was a clear implication from Senator Collins that the decision was made after the review had been put on hold. It is in the Hansard twice. I do not expect her to apologise, because she never does. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Health and Ageing. I hope for a sign of better faith from her than from the minister giving the previous answer. Can the minister confirm that home medicines reviews conducted by GPs and community pharmacists have been shown to be a very effective means of ensuring that medicines are prescribed, stored and used correctly at the least possible cost? Can the minister also confirm that at a cost of $154 per review undertaken the Howard government funded 18,900 reviews in the last financial year, at a total cost of $1.95 million? Given the effectiveness of these reviews, why doesn't the government take the $27 million it is currently wasting on a massive television advertising campaign and spend it instead on an extra 175,000 home medicines reviews this year?

—It is quite difficult to get a dorothy dixer on this side, so it is great when I get them from the other side. It is absolutely fantastic to have the chance to tell the Australian public about the home medicines reviews that the Howard government introduced. The Labor Party did nothing about the PBS, and you still do nothing. You brought in a copayment—you increased it—and because it was fiscally responsible we agreed with it. When we want to do something that is fiscally responsible, you will not support us.

answer.para: I have just told you that we put three medications on the PBS which will cost $700 million over four years. Let me just say that the Home Medicines Review program has been highly successful. It has involved training pharmacists to go out into people's homes mainly. Some of the reviews are done in pharmacies, but mainly they are done in people's homes.

talk.start.para: —We agree with it!

—Senator Collins says they agree with it, so why didn't they do it when they were in government and the PBS was growing? They did nothing. They jacked up the copayment but did nothing else to protect the PBS. Under this program, a pharmacist goes out and talks to a person, usually a person who is taking a lot of medications and is at risk of polypharmacy—that is, a person who is at risk of adverse events because of taking far too many medications and also taking medications that may interact with over-the-counter medicines. Senator Jacinta Collins would not know this, but one of the problems is that somebody may be taking, for example, Alka-Seltzer with their medications not knowing that Alka-Seltzer has over 300 milligrams of aspirin in each tablet. The Home Medicines Review program also looks at what other complementary medicines people are taking.

answer.para: They are very good reviews, but they are not for everybody. There are some people who use a very small number of medications and who would never qualify for a home medicines review who need to be informed about the PBS. They need to make sure that they do not get scripts filled when they do not need them, and they need to understand how the PBS works. As I have said, it needs everybody. It needs the parliamentarians— and I wish you would behave as parliamentarians occasionally when there is an issue like the PBS—to take fiscally responsible decisions to make sure that there is at least a reasonable contribution from the person who actually takes the medication. When you did that, we supported it. When we bring something in, you will not support it. It takes parliamentarians, not necessarily politicians, to do something about it.

It also takes the pharmaceutical companies to do something about it, and we are working with them to try to reduce the misuse of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. It takes prescribers to actually know how much medication costs. They did not know, but those costs are now appearing on their software. We are giving them information. Part of the program we are running out is to give doctors information other than the information they get from pharmaceutical companies. It also needs the person who is actually getting the script, the patient, to take some responsibility. It requires everybody in the chain to make sure the PBS is used wisely and appropriately.

I heard Ms Gillard talk about the Home Medicines Review program—and maybe she needs to poke her head in until she knows a bit more about health—as though it were the only way to solve problems with the PBS. You need a multipronged approach. You need to go through things like we have. We have given information on medicines to consumers, and we have set up the Home Medicines Review program and residential medication management reviews. We have facilitated the use of a generic medicines program and put restrictions on prescription shopping and, through the National Prescribing Service, we run programs like `Common colds need commonsense' to reduce the use of antibiotics. We have been doing a range of things. It takes a multipronged program to address the rising and unsustainable cost of the PBS.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's assertion that the $27 million advertising blitz is actually an education and information campaign—and as a second attempt to Senator Evans's try—will the minister table comprehensive details about the education objectives of the campaign and all qualitative and quantitative research undertaken in constructing the campaign as well as commit to providing the Senate with all tracking research undertaken to evaluate the effectiveness of this alleged, but very expensive, information campaign, or will the government just sit on this too?
—As I said, the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme has gone from $1 billion in 1991—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —those on the other side wouldn't care—to we think over $5 billion this financial year. That level of growth is unsustainable. In some years it has grown 20 per cent; in other years, 14 per cent. It is the fastest growing part of the health budget. If we are going to have a PBS that the next generation can enjoy, we need to do something about preserving it. We need to educate people about it: we need to educate prescribers, we need to educate the pharmaceutical companies about a reasonable level of growth and we need to educate politicians on the other side that it is unsustainable and they have a responsibility to ensure that the PBS is sustainable into the future so that the next generation can enjoy it.

answer.para: I thank Senator Collins for the question because it gave me the opportunity to reinforce and tell people again how wonderful the PBS is but how difficult it is to sustain if we do not get everyone working on it, including those people on the opposite side of the chamber.

talk.start.para: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

debateinfo.title: QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE: TAKE NOTE OF ANSWERS

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Hill) and the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts (Senator Alston) to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) and Senators Carr and Forshaw today relating to Dr Peter Shergold, AM, and the report `National Report on Australia's Higher Education Sector 2001'.

speech.para: The politicisation of the Australian Public Service is out of control, with news that the nation's most senior public servant, Dr Shergold, has now doctored an official report to please his political masters. The office of the Minister for Education, Science and Training, Brendan Nelson, has been directly involved in this shameful cover-up, contrary to the claims of Dr Nelson's staffer Ross Hampton—that is, Mr `Children Overboard'—and also a letter from the current education chief, Dr Jeff Harmer, which was tabled in the parliament yesterday.

The sorry tale began in 2001. In August 2001 the education department commissioned the writing of one of the most important reports, the second in a series of 10-year snapshots of the higher education system: the National Report on Australia's Higher Education Sector. It was a very big deal. The best educational brains in the country, both inside the department and outside the department, were assembled—19 separate consultancies tendered, 22 separate consultants were engaged and about 12 of the best brains in the department were put together.

The cornerstone report was completed before Easter 2002. In March 2002 two briefs were prepared for the minister: an alert brief and a longer brief. The then head of the department, Dr Peter Shergold, saw the report and he was not happy. He insisted that chapters 4 and 7 of the report be heavily edited. Line responsibility for this surgery was given to the current head of the higher education group, Mr Bill Burmester. Key sections of this report which challenged the oft repeated view that the Howard government's 1996 HECS changes had no equity impact were cut. The work showed that the HECS changes had discouraged students from lower socioeconomic groups and led to a sharp decline in the numbers studying high-cost subjects such as medicine, law and dentistry. The new research challenged the established wisdom on these issues. It shone a spotlight on the government's policy, and it did not look very good at all. It turned out that ability was not all you needed under a Howard government to get into university. It showed that a credit card was also required.

The data should have formed a critical part of the debate in the run-up to the government's Crossroads review. The public should have known that this research was available. The public could have decided whether or not it was a reasonable proposition. The public were denied the facts on these matters. The cover-up in fact was completely inept because at the end of the year we saw that the national report had not been doctored and only after I asked some questions in this chamber on 19 March this year was it demonstrated that key consultancy reports had not been reported in the annual report last year and that the report itself had been suppressed. Of course that led to the train of events where the doctored version of the report was finally issued on 23 July this year.

The question lies with the minister. I call on him to come clean about the processes and his office's direct involvement in the censoring of this report. It defies belief that the minister's office was not made aware of the complete report 15 months ago. It is of course like the `children overboard' scandal where the minister seeks to claim that there are firewalls operating. Because it goes to the minister's office and to the minister's advisers, he turns around and says, `It has not come to me personally.' The department have shown us in the Senate estimates that they direct their communications to the minister. It is totally inappropriate for the minister now to turn around and say, `I personally did not know anything about it; it was only my advisers.' The suppression of this critical data expresses shameful contempt for this parliament and scant regard for due consultative processes and the democratic system of engaging the public in significant public policy issues.

talk.start.para: —One of the first things that I learnt when I was a young student was that, if you have to shout and raise your voice to get your point across, you usually do not have much substance in what you are saying. Can I say that Senator Carr has proved that point conclusively today. There was very little substance in what he said. One of the other issues is that I always understood that this half an hour was set aside for people to respond to answers to questions. In fact Senator Carr did not respond to the answers that were given to the questions today; he came in with a prepared statement that was written long before question time so that he could put his point of view across and debate the issue without taking into account any content of the answers that were provided by Senator Alston and Senator Hill. If the opposition want to use this period of time to take note of answers, they ought to be listening to the answers and responding to the answers they get, not coming in here with a prepared statement so that they can add to the debate of issues that they want to put on the record which in fact bear no relation to the answers that were given by the minister.

speech.para: What the minister did say in response to the questions that were asked by Senator Carr and others today, and amongst the key points that Senator Carr ought to have been noting, was that the second national report on higher education was published by the Department of Education, Science and Training. It was an initiative of the department, not of any minister. It was the department itself that commissioned this report, and so it is the department itself that was responsible for it. The purpose of the report—again, which Senator Carr was not very interested in—was to provide the department's retrospective view on policy and on other developments in the sector between 1992 and 2001. That covers the period from the introduction of the HECS scheme by the Labor government at that time, who deemed it necessary for students to make some contribution to their higher education. I had three daughters involved in the scheme until the late 1990s, and one still has not finished paying back the HECS contribution. She considers it to be a fair way of receiving an education and that she should have the opportunity to pay for it at some later stage.

The higher education adviser saw several drafts of the report and then suggested some minor improvements. Senator Carr took no notice whatsoever of that part of the answer but wanted to continue with his own ravings—rather loudly, I must say—when he said to the Senate all of the things that he wanted to say, that he had prepared prior to listening to the minister's answer. The material that had required minor improvements related to the impact of HECS, and it was edited out of this draft and subsequent drafts by the department. It had nothing whatsoever to do with the minister. If Senator Carr had cared to listen to the answer that Minister Alston gave, he would have noted that the secretary of the department had advised the minister that the department had edited material out of the report in November last year before it was provided to the minister's education adviser for comments because—and this is the part that is important—of the department's concern in relation to the methodological difficulties inherent in analysis of this kind and the incompleteness and inconclusiveness of some of the findings, which meant that it did not have a valid place in the report.

That answer was given specifically by the minister to Senator Carr's question and to other questions by senators on that side, yet Senator Carr chose to ignore completely the response that was provided by the minister and go off on a tangent of his own—on his own little frolic, putting his own propaganda forward and putting his own slant on everything that occurred in the department—to suit his own political purpose. It would do Senator Carr and the Labor Party much more good to come up with some draft policy of their own—some draft policy that they might put to the Australian public—because they have not, and it seems they cannot decide on what their policy should be. In the meantime, all they can do is criticise all of the good work that is being done by this minister and by the department that advises him on what—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Senator Ferguson commenced his comments by referring to when he was a student and to some of the things that he apparently learned as a student. One of the things that he should have learned is that, when you are asked a question, good scholarship demands that you actually answer the question. But what we have seen today from the ministers that were asked questions in regard to this most important issue raised during question time is that the questions were not answered. If you want to talk about obfuscation, shouting and abuse, you have the perfect example of that again from Senator Alston in his response to the question that I asked. He did not deal at all with the question. He went off on a frolic of his own, because quite clearly (1) he knew that he did not know the answer and (2) he also suspected that the answer that he might get from the department or from the minister would prove the point of the question. Senator Carr has outlined quite clearly in his remarks that there has been interference, there has been cover-up and there has clearly been further politicisation, in this case of the Department of Education, Science and Training.

speech.para: Politicisation of the Public Service has become rampant under this government. We have seen plenty of examples of where the Public Service has been prevented, either deliberately or by other means, from providing impartial and factual advice to this government. We saw it in the evidence that came out in the `children overboard' inquiry. We have seen it more recently in respect of the issue of the weapons of mass destruction and Iraq's capacity to produce nuclear weapons. It is now acknowledged that the Office of National Assessments had information that the claims that were about to be made by the Prime Minister about Iraq were false. They had that information before the Prime Minister made his speech, but he nevertheless went ahead and misled the parliament and the people with regard to that matter.

Let us come back to the issues that were specifically raised in questions by Senator Carr, Senator Faulkner and me with respect to this cover-up in the higher education area. It is quite clear that the Minister for Education, Science and Training had the draft report provided to his office. But the secretary of the department claimed that that had not occurred. Evidence was given at the Senate estimates hearing on 5 June this year that the final draft version of the report was sent to the minister in the first quarter of the year. Yet what does the secretary of the department say in a letter to his minister? That it was not provided before 21 July this year. You just cannot reconcile those two claims. Clearly, given all the other evidence, the people who are to be believed are the departmental officers who gave evidence to the Senate estimates committee.

Dr Shergold is the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. At the time of this situation, when he clearly interfered in the drafting of that report to ensure that certain elements and information compiled by the department would not see the light of day, he was the Secretary to the Department of Education, Science and Training. It is interesting to note Dr Shergold's response to claims that there has been politicisation. He had the temerity to say, `It's absolute balderdash and poppycock.' Everybody in the country knows that the Public Service is being politicised more and more and that decent public servants are being prevented from doing their job of providing impartial advice because of the actions of ministers and ministerial advisers. Dr Shergold also said this, when commenting about the ONA:

quote.para: Intelligence, I've discovered in my time in this department is a remarkably difficult area ...

speech.para: I think Dr Shergold is speaking about himself there, because he clearly cannot understand the right and proper role of the Public Service in providing advice—

talk.start.para: —The case which has been put to the Senate today by those opposite for the politicisation of the Public Service seems to me to rest on extremely tenuous grounds. The circumstances of this particular report being made available to the office of the Minister for Education, Science and Training prior to it being published have been taken up by the Secretary to the Department of Education, Science and Training. It is evident from what those opposite have said that they do not believe that secretary. They do not believe what the head of the department of education told his minister and said on the public record. They obviously do not believe his predecessor Dr Shergold either in respect of the things he has had to say about this matter.

speech.para: We are seeing a systematic attempt by those opposite, both in this chamber and in the other chamber, to tar public servants who work at senior levels with the claim that they have been politicised by virtue of their association with this government. That is what is taking place. The politicisation which is occurring is a matter of opposition members choosing to taint those who work for this government with the brush of being politically associated with the objectives of the government. The fact is that the Public Service, in serving all levels of the government federally, does its job well, effectively and apolitically. The evidence to the contrary which we have heard here today is weak in the extreme.

We have been told that there has been interference. We have been told that there has been a cover-up. Where precisely is the evidence of a cover-up? A report has been made available to the minister's office. The report, according to the minister and the secretary of the minister's department, was made available in November 2002. Material relating to the effect of the HECS scheme on demand for higher education places was certainly removed from that report at some point prior to the report being made available to the minister. That seems to be agreed. But where is the evidence that the minister, the minister's adviser or somebody on the minister's behalf, got on the phone to the department and said, `Take that stuff out'? Where is the evidence of that? There is not any.

The evidence that we have been given today is Senator Carr saying, `It defies belief that the minister's office was not made aware' of that doctoring. Senator Forshaw told us that everyone `knows that the Public Service is being politicised'. With great respect, before we drag the reputations of senior public servants through this place, it behoves us to produce some solid evidence that they have behaved inappropriately. I have met Dr Harmer and I think he is a man of integrity. I have met Dr Shergold and I have the same view of his character. And I note that Dr Shergold and Mr Max Moore-Wilton before him have received the same withering treatment from those opposite, which is to say that if they work at such a level for a Liberal government they must necessarily be Liberal sympathisers and therefore incapable of serving a government of the other persuasion. That is the message I get, and I think that that is most unfortunate. What we are seeing in this exercise is Dr Shergold getting the Max Moore-Wilton treatment, and that is undeserved.

The fact is that the reports which have been considered so damning have now been made available by the minister. The minister was happy to put those on the table in the light of this controversy to demonstrate that the government has nothing to hide about those documents. But he has pointed out that there were real methodological questions about their validity. There were real questions about how much value could be placed on some of those reports into the workings of Australia's higher education system. Fair enough. That was the view—according to the secretary of the department—of the department of education. It was their decision. I ask again: where is the evidence that it was not their decision? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I commend Senator Humphries for at least addressing the substantive nature of this debate, on speaking on the same matter. He asks, `Where is the evidence?' Let us address that issue. But firstly, I would like to say that this is not a tenuous personal attack on Dr Shergold. I doubt that Dr Shergold, for instance, would accuse me of withering treatment in relation to his position. What this argument is about is a further demonstration of yet another example of the integrity problems at the core of the Howard government. It is difficult these days to remember that phrase `honest John Howard'. This is another one of those examples. This is a case of the government, it is alleged—and we are having great difficulties getting the information to prove otherwise—excising important information from critical reports: on this occasion, higher education; on past occasions, hepatitis. This is akin to that problem that has been named `plausible deniability'. It is one of the critical credibility problems for this government. I am, because of past history, quite critical of the letter that has been tabled from Dr Harmer. Why am I critical? Because if you read the second paragraph on the second page, it does not say that the material had been taken out of the draft provided to the minister's office; it simply says the decision to remove all material had been made. I would like to know when that material was removed.

speech.para: The other difficulty is that we have reports that this report did go to the minister's office as early as April, not November as reported in this letter. Now that was at a point when Dr Harmer was not secretary of the department. The question here is: when Dr Shergold was secretary, was that material passed over? It was not to the knowledge of Dr Harmer. We are not accusing Dr Harmer—or certainly I am not, from what I am aware of to date—of providing inaccurate information. The question is: is he providing incomplete information and why will Dr Shergold not respond directly to the reports that have been made? He has had four days to deny what has been reported in the Sydney Morning Herald: that it was he, Dr Shergold, who directly sought to have this material excised, and that it was to be excised because it was inconvenient to the government. Now, this is the Dr Shergold who, despite his claims of non-politicisation or of being nonpartisan as a public servant, also says some other very interesting things.

Senator Carr will recall, as I do, when he rolled up to estimates with a trolley load of material, with the press gallery already briefed about how much money it was going to cost the Commonwealth in answering Senate estimates questions—one of the most partisan pieces of behaviour I have ever seen in estimates, but of course this report was not on the trolley, was it? Of course not! I also remember when Dr Shergold politicised DEWRSB by seeking to impose Australian workplace agreements throughout that department. At the same time he is politicising these departments, he goes to the Prime Minister's office and claims that he is nonpartisan. Let us quote Dr Shergold, because he said, for instance, in a recent speech he gave:

quote.para: In truth, I not infrequently fail to live up to the rhetoric I espouse.

speech.para: And this is another example of failure to live up to his own rhetoric. His rhetoric, though, was that:

quote.para: Our advice should seek not only to have honesty and integrity, but to be imaginative and innovative. Creativity is critical.

speech.para: I wonder if that creativity is what guided Ross Hampton in what he did in the children overboard affair, when he created an impression that things occurred at night, to avoid critical evidence that was going to damage the government, or is it that attitude of creativity that guided, on this occasion, Dr Nelson's adviser Ross Hampton—previously with Minister Reith—to deny that the minister had tampered with the report? He said:

quote.para: There's been no dialogue, correspondence or any form of discussion between the minister or anyone in his office about the report ...

speech.para: We now know from Dr Harmer that Ross Hampton is misleading us again. He has form, the government has form and Dr Shergold, unfortunately, has form too. (Time expired)
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer (Senator Coonan) to a question without notice asked by Senator Cherry today relating to the definition of charities.

speech.para: This is a very important matter, which the government has now publicly acknowledged: there is a second bill to deal with the definition of charities. The first bill was, of course, tabled by the Treasurer on 22 July and has caused serious concern in the charitable sector because of the definitions which appear to limit the concessions available to charities to only those charities which are not seeking to change government policy. Of course the Treasurer, at the time, said the definition in that bill purely reflected the common law. In actual fact, the common law in this area that he was relying on is something like 20 years old, and the definition which the government is proposing is a very narrow view. In fact it was expressly rejected in the most recent common law case to deal with the definition of charities, in October last year, in the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal, concerning the ACF.

In her answer the minister said that the consequential amendments bill only contained technical matters and that there was no substantial policy difference. We were told that the charities definition in the bill only contained a codification of current law. But, on examination of the exposure draft, this is not the case. So I call on the government quite clearly to release the consequential amendments bill to ensure that the charity sector can look at it. I also call on the government, quite emphatically, to release its response to the rest of the Charities Definition Inquiry report. There is some good stuff in the Charities Bill that the government released in July. It included a wider definition of charity than that contained in the current common law, and I think the government deserves credit for that. It recognises that the definition of charities should be extended to self-help groups, and it includes a much wider definition of advancement in terms of the purposes of charities.

There is some very good stuff in this bill, and the bill would be a very good one if the issue of disqualifying purposes for criticising government could be fixed—there would be a very significant advance in the laws covering charities. The problem is that most of the tax concessions associated with charities are only associated with a very narrow category of charities called `public benevolent institutions', which was a result of the response of the Bruce-Page government in 1927 to a Privy Council decision. That particular definition has been found to be more and more narrow by the various courts. In fact, the key decision that defined a public benevolent institution goes back to 1931. The Australian Taxation Office, based on that decision—the Perpetual Trustees case—describes a public benevolent institution as a `non-profit institution organised for the direct relief of such poverty, sickness, suffering, distress, misfortune, disability, destitution and helplessness as arouses compassion in the community'.

Every single one of those words in that tax office ruling creates legal problems. There has been a flurry of cases trying to tease out what they mean, and the cases conflict with each other. What they keep coming back to, as evidenced in the RSPCA case—which found that the RSPCA could not be a public benevolent institution—is that the `present approach derives from decisions of the High Court of Australia and that it should be left to that court to formulate a new test if one is to be adopted'. In other words, the common law has atrophied in the area of the most important issue for charities, which is access to PBI status. That is why the Charities Definition Inquiry said that we need to get rid of this definition. We need to update it, improve it, make it more comprehensive, make it more modern and make it more readable.

At the end of the committee's report is recommendation 21, an important recommendation, which is that the category of public benevolent institutions be replaced by a subset of charities to be known as benevolent charities—that is, a charity whose dominant purpose is to benefit directly or indirectly those whose disadvantage prevents them from meeting their needs. That recommendation was made over two years ago. The government is yet to respond to it. The government has responded to the rest of the Charities Definition Inquiry report but not to its key recommendation. On that recommendation rests access to the most important concessions that charitable institutions can get in this country. On that recommendation rests the fundamental issue of updating law that is over 80 years old so that we can ensure that our tax system does whatever it can to alleviate distress, wherever it is in our sector. That is why the Democrats call on the government to respond in full to that report, which has now been on the table for two years. We call on the government to release its consequential amendments report to ensure a fairer deal for charities.
Question agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I asked a question in what I thought was a very mild manner, seeking information from the Minister for Health and Ageing as to what progress had been made by the government in putting the requirement on drug companies to declare whether a drug has been created, tested or manufactured using human embryos or human embryonic stem cells.

speech.para: Unfortunately, the minister's reply told me that nothing has been done since June. For example, the minister said that this proposal of mine might require companies to track information on drugs produced 20 years ago. I was aware of that argument, and I believe that argument was finished by 19 June. In a letter that I wrote to the Hon. Trish Worth, with whom I have had very respectful negotiations, I indicated that there were number of issues relating to testing which could be negotiated to find an acceptable outcome, including the time boundaries of my request. In my letter I said:

quote.para: Pharmaceutical companies do not need to track down information on drugs produced twenty years ago—just on drugs or components manufactured from, say, 2003 onwards;

speech.para: So it was answered there, and I had hoped to get some response. I know a lot of colleagues on all sides of the parliament realise the importance of a consumer's right to know. I seek leave to incorporate my letter to the Hon. Trish Worth MP and also a letter from Professor Michael Good, who is the Director, Queensland Institute of Medical Research, which shows that this is not an overburdensome requirement that might be made of drug companies.
Leave granted.
19 June 2003
The Hon Trish Worth MP
Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Ms Worth

Thank you for your letter of 19 June regarding the Therapeutic Goods Administration's draft Report on Information and Advertising Associated with Products Tested, Created or Manufactured using Human Embryos or Human Embryonic Stem Cells.
While I am prepared to consider compromise on some aspects of my proposed amendments, others are central to providing basic consumer information.

I appreciate your offer to make it necessary to have specific ministerial direction to make changes to the particular guidelines. I would like details of how that arrangement would operate effectively in practical terms and how it would be accountable to Parliament. It would need, for instance, to include arrangements for a statement detailing the change and reasons for the change to be tabled in Parliament and printed in the TGA's annual report.
I am still concerned however that the guidelines will not offer consumers any more information than would already be available under current arrangements.

The issue of testing drugs is important to consumers precisely because it is anticipated to be one of the main uses of human embryos or human embryonic stem cells under the Research Involving Human Embryos Act, passed late last year. I would appreciate the opportunity to explore with you the various ways my concerns could be accommodated.
There are a number of issues relating to testing which could be negotiated to find an acceptable outcome, including:

· The time boundaries of my request. Pharmaceutical companies do not need to track down information on drugs produced twenty years ago—just on drugs or components manufactured from, say, 2003 onwards;

· The reasonable knowledge of pharmaceutical companies. The requirement could apply to information in the possession of the pharmaceutical company or what they could reasonably be expected to know. I find it hard to believe drug companies would not have very good data on testing; and,
· The requirement might only apply to drugs put to market after 1 January 2003 and not to drugs which were originally produced and put to market before that date.
There are ways around the potential problems you have listed and I would appreciate the chance, with good will from both sides, to find a way forward.
In return, I am prepared to consider a compromise position to:
· Agree to change my proposed amendments so that they include the word “manufacture” rather than the word “creation”;
· Drop my proposal that this amendment be included in legislation, subject to clarification of the operation of the ministerial direction;
· Drop my proposal for the information to be included in drug advertising; and,
· Discuss any further requests you may have.
I would appreciate the opportunity to discuss this with you, or if you prefer, for our staff to liaise on this issue to find a way to inform consumers on the central issue of testing.
Yours sincerely
(signed)
BRIAN HARRADINE
Queensland Institute of Medical Research
Senator Brian Harradine
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator,

It has been brought to my attention this afternoon that information from the Member for Adelaide, the Hon, Trish Worth, Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Ageing, regarding the issue of labelling drugs with respect to the use of human embryo cell lines in their development and workup. The current procedure is that all drugs licensed by TGA must have an “Investigational Brochure”. This brochure contains all information relevant to the development, testing and manufacture of the drug. Such information would include the preclinical efficacy testing, which might very well involve the response of different cell lines to the drug or to related products of the drug. It would involve information relevant to the pre-clinical toxicology (in other words whether the medication demonstrated any harmful effects to animals or cell lines) and it would of course involve pre-clinical efficacy in sub-human species (typically mice and non-rodent species) and data on safety and efficacy in human studies. The TGA must hold a copy of the brochure for each and every drug that is licensed and In doing so it adheres to the International Convention for Harmonisation Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice.

My understanding is that the TGA could expect to collect information relevant to the use of human embryonic stem cells involved in the development of new drugs without a great degree of difficulty. It may be more difficult to collect such information retrospectively on currently registered drugs.
Yours sincerely,
(signed)
Michael Good
Director

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

motion.para: That the Senate--

speech.para: (1) Endorses the Government's decision to deploy the Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands.

(2) Expresses its support for the members of the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Defence Force, the Australian Protective Service, Australian Government officials, and personnel from Pacific Island nations who are deployed with the assistance mission.
(3) Expresses its full confidence in the members of the assistance mission, and its hope for a successful mission and their safe return home.

In support of the motion I have just moved, I seek leave to incorporate the Prime Minister's speech on this subject, which was or is being made in the House of Representatives. I do so with the intention of saving valuable Senate time.
Leave granted.
Mr Speaker, today I wish to report to the Senate on the Australian-led Regional Assistance Mission to the Solomon Islands (RAMSI).

I am pleased to note at the outset that the mission has received overwhelming support from the people of the Solomon Islands and that cooperation among the various force elements from the Pacific Islands Forum nations has been close and effective.

It would, however, be premature to declare the problems solved. The work of the mission has only just begun. Risks remain and we know that the Solomon Islands will need the help and encouragement of its friends for some time to come.

The Solomon Islands faces many obstacles to its development. It is geographically isolated and its small population base is fractured. Even beyond the damage caused by the ethnic tensions that erupted in 1998, corruption has strangled many of the institutions vital to good governance, and violence has become endemic.

The Solomon Islands Government has recognised that it is unable to address its problems or, indeed, govern effectively—they know that if they do not stop the slide into chaos their nation will collapse. The Prime Minister of the Solomon Islands, Sir Allan Kemakeza wrote to the Prime Minister on 22 April providing a very frank assessment of the problems besetting the Solomon Islands and seeking our support. On 5 June, they met in Canberra to discuss the situation.

Given the long-standing strong ties between our nations and our peoples, it is no surprise the Solomon Islands should turn to Australia for assistance. Australia has provided support and aid to the Solomon Islands over many years. Many Australians have lived and worked there, building a reservoir of personal connections and engagement.

In response to earlier problems, we were instrumental in facilitating and supporting the conclusion and implementation by the Solomon Islanders of the Townsville Peace Agreement in 2000 and the subsequent International Peace Monitoring team, which helped to end inter-ethnic conflict.

But it is clear that despite these efforts, the problems facing the Solomon Islands have grown more serious. Criminal lawlessness has replaced ethnic tension. And most critically, some of the main culprits are in the police force. The country's institutions have been greatly weakened and have, in some cases, turned against the people they are meant to serve. This has contributed to a severe economic decline, which in turn exacerbates the climate of political and social instability.
Over the last six years, per capita GDP has been halved, falling below US$500 in 2002. The Solomon Islands economy contracted by 14 per cent in 2000 and by another nine per cent in 2001.

Earlier this year, critical social welfare infrastructure had almost ceased to function. There were no funds for vital medicines and hospital supplies. Power generation was essentially crippled—unable to supply hospitals, schools or business. Lack of power has also affected the water supply, already seriously degraded by poor maintenance.

Those employed by the Solomon Islands Government to provide vital services have not been paid for months at a time. Many of them demonstrated great loyalty and compassion by continuing to work regardless of whether they were paid or not.

All the while a small group of criminals and militants have been looting the very future of the Solomons. They have terrorised the community— brought the nation to the very brink of collapse— and done a grave disservice to the reputation of the Solomon Islanders as a good and generous people.

Innocent villages have been brutalised as rival criminal gangs jostle for control. Over 1000 people have had to flee the Weathercoast to seek refuge in Honiara. Sir Alfred Soaki, the former police commissioner and National Peace Councillor was assassinated in February this year. Cabinet Minister Father Augustine Geve was killed in August last year.

Kidnapping, murder, rape and torture have gone unchecked. Police are unable or unwilling to investigate many of these crimes. There are too many examples of criminals evading arrest, charges or detention, protected by corrupt politicians, officials, police or prison guards.
It is vital that we do all that we can to arrest this downward spiral, which, if not addressed, could result in the total collapse of the Solomon Islands' governance and sovereignty.

The international community looks to Australia to play a leading role in the South Pacific. Our leadership of the regional assistance mission to the Solomon Islands reflects both a national interest and an international expectation.

A failed state would not only devastate the lives of the peoples of the Solomons but could also pose a significant security risk for the whole region.
