debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 September 2002:

question.para: With reference to the answer to question on notice no. 2889 (House of Representatives Hansard, 22 June 1998, p.5112):
(1) What is the: (a) peacetime establishment; and (b) current staffing strength, of each unit in the Australian Army.
(2) What is the: (a) peacetime establishment; and (b) current staffing strength, of each unit in the Royal Australian Air Force.
(3) What is the: (a) peacetime establishment; and (b) current staffing strength, of each unit in the Royal Australian Navy.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: I am unable to release publicly the kind of detailed information sought by the honourable senator as it is national security classified. The information can, however, be provided to the Shadow Minister for Defence on a confidential basis if so requested.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 14 March 2003:

question.para: (1) With reference to the answer to question no. 6 taken on notice during the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee's supplementary estimates hearings on 21 November 2002, was the `direction from the Government' to introduce a new process to prevent the concealment of claims by Australian Defence Force (ADF) members under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 from the Department of Defence, made by the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, or the Prime Minister.

(2) Does the answer contradict that given by the department on 21 November 2002 that the Privacy Act 1988 prevented the department giving information on claims from serving members of the ADF to the Department of Defence.
(3) Does the answer also contradict the answer given to part (1) of question on notice no. 1011 (Senate Hansard, 4 February 2003, p. 8486).
(4) Was legal advice sought to clarify the matter; if so: (a) from whom; and (b) can a copy of this advice be provided.
(5) Was advice sought from the Privacy Commissioner; if so: (a) was the advice in writing; and (b) can a copy of this advice be provided.

(6) Has agreement been reached with the Department of Defence on a new process for the Department of Veterans' Affairs to provide Defence with details of claims made or accepted under the Veterans' Entitlements Actby serving personnel; if not, has a date been set to achieve this; if a date has not been set, why not.
(7) Has the Department of Defence sought information on such claims since 5 January 2003; if so, has a response containing the details been provided.

(8) Are liabilities for compensation granted to serving ADF members included in the total compensation liability incurred under the Act for the Department of Defence in relation to the ADF; if so, what is the estimated current liability for: (a) all veterans; (b) all ex-service personnel with defence service only; and (c) all current serving ADF personnel receiving payments for: (i) defence service injuries, and (ii) operational service injuries.
(9) What is the total estimated current liability for compensation payments for service-related injury and illness accepted under the Military Compensation Scheme, including its predecessor schemes.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Minister for Veterans' Affairs asked the Department of Defence and the Department of Veterans' Affairs (DVA) to liaise about the provision of information held for the purpose of claims under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA).

(2) No. On 21 November 2002 at the Senate Estimates hearing, DVA staff noted the possibility that the Privacy Act 1988 may present the provision of such information but undertook to take the Question on Notice. The answer was later provided as a response to Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee Question on Notice no. 6 asked on that day.

(3) No. The response to part (1) of Question on Notice no. 1011 correctly stated that it would contravene the provisions of Privacy Principle (IPP) 11 for DVA to routinely provide claims information to the Department of Defence. While personal information may be provided on specific individuals who are currently serving in the ADF, the practical and legal issue is the lawful ability of the Department of Defence to identify to the Department of Veterans Affairs, in accordance with the Privacy Act, the persons about whom VEA information could be sought.

(4) Internal legal advice was sought and that advice was, in effect, incorporated in the response to Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Legislation Committee Question on Notice no. 6. No external legal advice was sought.
(5) No advice was sought or provided by the Privacy Commissioner.

(6) The Department of Defence has identified a process that should ensure that the medical officer responsible for assessing a member's fitness, including for deployment, is made aware of any claims the member may have under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. The process would entail case by case access to DVA claim details rather than Defence access to all Department of Veterans' Affairs claims. The process requires development and an implementation date has not been set.
(7) Since 5 January 2003, there have been no requests by the Department of Defence for information held by DVA.
(8) No. The Department of Veterans' Affairs does not keep separate records of disability pensions paid under the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 to current members of the ADF.
(9) At July 2002 the Commonwealth Actuary's estimate of liability under the SRCA was $1.3b.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 30 April 2003:

question.para: (1) (a) How many staff currently hold: (i) ongoing, and (ii) non-ongoing, positions in the Human Rights Branch; and (b) what is the Australian Public Service (APS) level of these positions.
(2) (a) How many ongoing and non-ongoing staff based elsewhere in the department are working on human rights matters; and (b) what is the APS level of these staff.
(3) (a) Which positions are currently vacant in the Human Rights Branch; and (b) how long have they been vacant.
(4) Since the additional estimates hearings in February 2003, how many staff have left the Human Rights Branch.
(5) What is currently the average period of service of staff in the Human Rights Branch.

(6) Since the additional estimates hearings in February 2003, what has been the absentee rate for: (a) sick leave (including workers compensation leave); (b) annual leave; (c) miscellaneous paid leave; and (d) long service leave, in the Human Rights Branch, and in the department as a whole.
(7) What involvement did the Human Rights Branch have in the development of the Australian Human Rights Commission Bill 2003.

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Attorney-General provides the following information based on advice from the Attorney-General's Department current as at 26 May 2003:

(1) 12 on-going and 4 non-ongoing staff in the Human Rights Branch work on human rights matters. Seven other staff who hold ongoing positions in the Branch are elsewhere. Three are acting in higher level positions outside the Branch, one is on leave to work in the Attorney-General's office, and three are overseas (studying, accompanying a partner and doing volunteer work). The following table sets out the APS levels of positions in the Branch:

(2) The other key area of the Department that works on human rights matters is the Office of International Law. As at 26 May 2003 there were three staff within the Office of International Law who worked primarily on human rights matters. As at 26 May 2003 they were all non-ongoing. Their APS levels are one acting Principal Legal Officer and two Senior Legal Officers. Recruitment is underway for filling of the Principal Legal Officer and one Senior Legal Officer position on an ongoing basis. The other Senior Legal Officer position is substantively filled on an ongoing basis by an officer who is on leave. There is also a Legal Officer in the Office of International Law who works both on human rights matters and on general international law matters as required. That position is, as at 26 May 2003, filled on a non-ongoing basis. The position is substantively filled on an ongoing basis by an officer who is on other duties elsewhere in the Department.
In addition, human rights issues come up in a wide range of areas, so from time to time officers across the department may be dealing with human rights issues.

(3) At 26 May 2003 action was being taken to recruit three further staff and an additional person on a temporary basis. As a result, from 2 June two staff have been engaged on a non-ongoing basis. Recruitment action for the other two staff, for positions vacant since 12 May 2003 and 23 May 2003, is ongoing.

(4) Between 18 February 2003 and 26 May 2003, three ongoing staff left the Human Rights Branch. In addition, two ongoing staff left temporarily to act in higher level positions outside the Branch and one who was non-ongoing in the Division left at the end of a period of acting in a higher level position in the Branch.

(5) As at 26 May 2003, the average period of service in the Branch for staff currently working in the Branch who are ongoing in the Division is slightly over 13 months. The average period of service in the Branch for current non-ongoing staff is 4.6 months.
(6) For the period February to April 2003, inclusive, Departmental records indicate the following leave levels:
(7) The Human Rights Branch provided advice and support to the Attorney-General and to the Government in the development of the Australian Human Rights Commission Bill 2003.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 June 2003:

question.para: In relation to the sale of the Crows Nest Barracks site at Queenscliff in Victoria:
(1) When was the decision taken to sell the property.
(2) When was the property sold.
(3) Which organisation purchased the property.
(4) What was the sale price for the property.

(5) Why did the property not appear in the full list of proposed Defence property sales for the 2002-03 financial year as provided in the response to question on notice no. 337 (Senate Hansard, 19 August 2002, p.3205).

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The property was originally identified for disposal in 2003-2004 . However, at the request of the Government it was reported to the Inter-Departmental Committee at its August 2002 meeting as a `reserve' property for potential sale in financial year 2002/03. Subsequently, Government approved the sale of the Crows Nest Barracks property in the 2002-2003 Property Disposal Program on 9 December 2002.
(3) The name of the organisation that purchased the property is Commercial-in-Confidence until the transfer is registered.
(4) The sale price of the property is Commercial-in-Confidence.
(5) Government agreement to the sale had not been given at that time.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 11 June 2003:

question.para: Given the proposed construction and operation of a links golf course on the Henley floodplain of the Yarra River involving huge levee banks, total remodelling of the floodplain, and use of biocides and fertilisers:
(a) will the Minister guarantee that there will be no detrimental impacts on what is possibly the last viable population of Macquarie Perch left on the planet; and
(b) is the Minister prepared to intervene to stop this invidious project.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The proposed construction and operation of the golf course on the Yarra floodplain has been determined to be a controlled action under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. The controlling provisions are listed threatened species and communities. As such, the proposal will be subject to a rigorous assessment and approval process to ensure that all threatened species and communities, including Macquarie Perch, are adequately protected.
(b) See answer to (a).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to budget measures affecting the Pensioner Education Supplement (PES), and the 2003-04 Budget proposal to match PES payments to study periods, generating savings of $39.3 million over 4 years (Portfolio Budget Statements 2003-04, Family and Community Services Portfolio, p. 198):
(1) How many Disability Support Pension recipients, grouped by disability type, will be affected by restricted access to the PES between periods of study.

(2) Has research been conducted into the likely impact of removal of the PES for people with disabilities studying courses longer than one year in duration; if so, what were the findings and recommendations from that research.
(3) What types of study-associated costs does the PES covers.

(4) Is it true that the Education Entry Payment, referred to in estimates hearings as a payment which could assist with book purchase in place of the PES, is a one-off payment and will not, in fact, assist with the cost of books or other costs over multiple years of study.

(5) (a) Does the Government acknowledge there is a range of additional study costs specific to people with disabilities, some of which are not tied to periods of study but are ongoing between periods of study; and (b) what assistance will be offered to meeting these additional costs in the absence of the PES.
(6) Can figures be provided, by disability type and as a proportion of all students with disabilities in receipt of PES, on those disabled students who subsidise holiday income by taking up work.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Estimated number of Disability Support Pension recipients who will be affected by the measure over the 2003-04 summer break is 12 560.
Data on disability type (medical condition) of PES recipients is not available.
(2) Research to specifically address the likely impact of removal of the PES for people with disabilities studying courses longer than one year in duration has not been conducted.
(3) PES is designed to assist with the ongoing incidental costs of study such as transport, fees, materials etc.
(4) The Education Entry Payment is available once every calendar year for continuing students.
(5) The type, extent and timing of additional study costs for students with a disability will depend on the nature of their disability.

Disability Support Pensioners receive PES at the full rate ($62.40 per fortnight) for part-time study whereas other PES recipients studying part-time receive half the full rate ($31.20 per fortnight).

Student pensioners also have access to a range of payments and concessions designed to respond to individual circumstances, including Mobility Allowance and the range of transport and other concessions attached to the Pensioner Concession Card.

Additionally, as part of the Commonwealth Budget for 2001-02, in the Australians Working Together package, $36.9m has been provided over 3 years for State and Territory efforts to assist people with a disability in education & training. It is intended that the funds should assist with the costs of additional places as well as associated learning supports.

(6) Data on earnings from employment split by disability type (medical condition) is not available for PES customers. The table below gives the total number of Disability Support Pensioners with earnings from employment, by medical condition, for 13 June 2003 (note that this point-in-time data).

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 18 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to budget measures affecting Disability Support Pension (DSP) reviews, and the 2003-04 Budget proposal to conduct an additional 61 000 DSP reviews, No. 79—18 June 2003 135 generating net savings of $89.2 million over 4 years (Portfolio Budget Statements 2003-04, Family and Community Services Portfolio, p. 187):

(1) Given that enhanced DSP reviews will require the development of new risk-profiling tools: (a) when will the department complete the development of the risk-profiling tool and guidelines for its implementation; and (b) will these guidelines be publicly available.
(2) As this measure contains implicit compliance requirements, what will be the penalty for DSP recipients who do not comply.
(3) How will people with disabilities and those with mental disorders be protected from incurring penalties.
(4) How will people who are homeless and on a DSP be protected from incurring penalties.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) The department, in conjunction with Centrelink, will complete the development of the risk-profiling tool and guidelines for its implementation by September 2003. (b) These guidelines will not be publicly available.
(2) Disability Support Pension (DSP) recipients who do not comply with the requirements of their review may have their payments stopped until they comply.

Payments are restarted and back payments made when recipients subsequently comply with their review, provided that they are still eligible for payment. Any debts discovered as part of the review will be required to be repaid.
(3) A number of strategies are used to assist people with disabilities and people with mental disorders to comply with their reviews.

These include allowing DSP recipients to nominate another person to be the contact for the review, giving more time to return their forms, issuing reminder letters, and giving time extensions or deferring reviews when they are experiencing difficulties.
(4) The same strategies are used to assist people who are homeless and on a DSP as those used to assist people with disabilities and people with mental disorders.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Family and Community Services, upon notice, on 30 May 2003:

question.para: With reference to budget measures affecting business services for people with disabilities, and the 2003-04 Budget proposal to provide $25.4 million over 3 years to assist business services to meet new quality assurance guidelines (Portfolio Budget Statements 2003-04, Family and Community Services Portfolio, p. 176).

(1) With reference to the estimate given at the Community Affairs Legislation Committee 2003-04 Budget estimates hearings in June 2003 that approximately one-third of business services are expected to have some difficulty in meeting new quality assurance requirements, how was this one-third estimate arrived at.
(2) How many employees does this one-third of business services represent.

(3) Given that approximately $5 million of the allocation will be spent on analyst assessments to ensure, in part, that businesses unlikely to ever be viable will not receive assistance: how many services may fall within this category.

(4) With regard to the new and ongoing voluntary reporting arrangements being introduced into business services, what role will business services undertake in relation to Centrelink customer income assessments.
(5) What guidelines have been developed by the department by which business services will report to Centrelink on customer income assessments.
(6) What is the link between business services' voluntary participation in customer income assessments and their capacity to demonstrate quality assurance compliance outcomes.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator Vanstone
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The estimate was based on risk assessments undertaken by FACS' State and Territory Offices against a number of national criteria.
(2) Approximately 5 000 people with disabilities. Risk levels are being closely monitored by FaCS.
(3) Reviews of business service organisations have only recently commenced. At this stage it is too early to identify those organisations that will not receive any funding flowing from their review.

(4) Business Services will have no role in Centrelink income assessments. Business Services are being asked to work with Centrelink to regularly report their employees' income to Centrelink through a process called Employer Reporting.
This initiative is one of a number of arrangements being put in place as part of Working Credit to assist people to report their earnings to Centrelink.

As part of the introduction of Working Credit on 20 September 2003, employment income will be measured on a fortnightly basis for all working-age income support payments. This will mean that people with income that varies each fortnight will need to report their income to Centrelink on a fortnightly basis.
Employer Reporting for Business Services is being introduced to provide an easy option for Business Services employees to meet these requirements.

If the customer has agreed to participate in Employer Reporting, the employer can transfer earnings information directly to Centrelink. Centrelink then uses the information to assess the customer's next payment. The earnings information is transferred via Centrelink's secure web site.
(5) A comprehensive range of information products and support tools have been developed to assist employers, customers and Centrelink staff in participating in Employer Reporting.
Centrelink has developed:
For employers:
· (in consultation with ACROD) a letter of introduction from National Manager DisAbility Services, Centrelink;
· a fact sheet for employers that explains Employer Reporting;
· a Service Partnership Agreement explaining the responsibilities of both the employer and Centrelink;
· a Security Undertaking committing the Business Service to security of payroll information and access passwords to Centrelink's website;
· a Security and Privacy fact sheet;
· a document explaining the content of the electronic file format required by Centrelink to accept and apply earnings information received from the employer;
· task cards to instruct employers in how to send electronic files to Centrelink;
· posters for the Business Service to advertise Centrelink information sessions; and
· flyers for distribution to employees to take home to advertise Centrelink information sessions and including a brief overview of Employer Reporting for carers/ nominees.

Centrelink will talk with each Business Service to determine the best way of providing information to their employees (eg via a seminar or interview). Local Centrelink staff will visit each Business Service and explain the changes to employees. A centralised helpdesk has also been established to assist Business Services with support and information.
(6) There is no link between this process and the quality assurance requirements.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 June 2003:

question.para: (1) How many Australian Defence civilians have applied for leave citing the war in Iraq as a reason.
(2) How many Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel have applied for leave citing the war in Iraq as a reason.
(3) Since March 2003, how many Australian Defence civilians have sought counselling, with payment for such counselling being made by the department.
(4) Since 20 March 2003, how many ADF personnel have sought counselling, with payment for such counselling being made by the department.
(5) How many Australian Defence civilians have attempted suicide since 20 March 2003.
(6) How many ADF personnel have attempted suicide since 20 March 2003.
(7) How many of the attempted suicides by Australian Defence civilians resulted in death.
(8) How many of the attempted suicides by ADF personnel resulted in death.
(9) Has the department conducted any surveys into suicides within the Australian Defence Forces.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) This information is not available. Defence civilian employees are not required to cite a reason when applying for their leave.
(2) This information is not available. Australian Defence Force (ADF) members are not required to cite a reason when applying for their leave.
(3) and (4) A variety of counselling services are available to Defence civilians and ADF personnel. Information on the number of personnel seeking counselling is not readily available.
(5) This information is not available.
(6) Eight ADF personnel have attempted suicide since 20 March 2003.
(7) There have been no civilian suicides in this period.
(8) Two.

(9) As part of the ADF Mental Health Strategy, the Defence Health Service monitors suicide statistics, researches and analyses trends, risk factors and underlying reasons for suicide and examines suicide prevention measures and their possible application within the ADF.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 19 June 2003:

question.para: With reference to the Commonwealth Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, under which the Australian Defence Force must not take action that has, will have, or is likely to have, a significant impact on the environment anywhere in the world without the approval of the Minister for Environment and Heritage:

(1) Did the Minister provide this approval prior to Australia's war on Iraq; if not, is the Minister aware that the unlawful taking of an action can attract a civil penalty of up to $1.1 million, or a criminal penalty of up to 2 years imprisonment.

(2) If the Minister was notified and gave approval for military action in Iraq by exempting the action under the Act, why is the exemption not listed under the public notices on the Environment Australia website.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) On 25 February 2003, I declared under subsection 28(3) of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999, in the interest of Australia's defence and security, that actions, as deemed appropriate by the Commonwealth Government, undertaken outside the Australian jurisdiction in relation to the training, deployment and operation of members of the Australian Defence Force in the Persian Gulf region in support of any military action against Iraq, are actions to which section 28 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 does not apply.
A declaration under section 28 of the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999 is not required to be published.
I am aware of the penalty provision associated with the unlawful taking of an action under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 27 June 2003:

question.para: (1) Can the Minister state whether the first 36 licences were allocated purely from the Commercial Radio Association (CRA) report or were other consultations undertaken and advice sought.
(2) How much of the total funding of $5 million is going to these first 36 licences.
(3) Is it true that all of the stations recommended to get licences in the CRA report were actually members of CRA.
(4) Was, or is, there any requirement that stations must be members of CRA to get licences.
(5) Did the report's terms of reference stipulate that only CRA members be included.
(6) How many of the communities given licences under this program already had commercial licenced broadcasts available.

(7) Given that the Northern Territory has many unserviced towns, including Nhulunbuy, Jabiru, Tennant Creek and the areas around them: were they included in the CRA report, among the total; if not, why not.

(8) Can the Minister explain and justify why several communities, for example, Cabramurra, Crookwell, Corryong (press release of 9th May 2003) have been given improved services when the Northern Territory has large areas with no services.
(9) (a) What is the proposed number of communities to be funded under this program; (b) is the total funding still $5 million; and (c) what is the timeline for completing the program.

(10) If the selection procedures were carried out with due diligence and impartiality, how are some communities allocated second and even third licences and improved services, when significant size communities elsewhere have nothing.
(11) Can the Minister guarantee that Northern Territory communities are on the list for future rounds of funding allocations.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) During the 2001 election the Government committed to fund 142 black spot communities identified in a Commercial Radio Australia (CRA - then known as the Federation of Australian Radio Broadcasters or FARB) submission. Funding is provided to existing commercial broadcasters to deliver services within their existing licence areas. No new licences were issued in this process. The Australian Broadcasting Authority was consulted in relation to planning issues prior to final funding approval.
(2) $1.05 million has been approved in the first round for 37 projects in 36 communities.

(3) All broadcasters awarded funding were identified in the original submission made to Government by CRA. The submission identified only CRA members. CRA represents 98% of the commercial radio industry in Australia.

(4) There is no requirement that broadcasters be members of CRA to be awarded funding under the Program. The Government's commitment to improving radio services in Australia is not limited to communities identified in the Government's 2001 election commitment.
(5) The CRA/FARB proposal did not include `terms of reference'. See also answer to part (1).
(6) 19 communities received funding for improved services rather than new services.
Funding was approved for the provision of:

· 18 new services to Kaniva/Nhill, Corryong, and Omeo in Victoria, and Alpha, Banana, Barcaldine, Blackall, Collinsville, Cooktown, Dirranbandi, Julia Creek, Karumba, Monto, Normanton, Richmond, Tambo, Weipa and Winton in Queensland;
· 11 new second services to Argyle, Cue, Dalwallinu, Eneabba, Jurien Bay, Kalbarri, Lancelin, Leeman, Leinster, Meekatharra and Perenjori in Western Australia; and
· 8 improved services to Cabramurra, Crookwell, Khancoban, and Talbingo in NSW, Corryong and Falls Creek in Victoria, and Mossman and St George in Queensland.

(7) Nhulunbuy, Jabiru and Tennant Creek were not among the 142 communities identified in the election commitment. The broadcaster responsible for servicing these communities was not nominated in CRA's proposal.

(8) The initial communities to be supported under the CRBP did not include communities in the Northern Territory. However, the program is being opened to invite further proposals. Commercial broadcasters in the Northern Territory will be able to submit proposals to be considered with other proposals in this context.
(9) (a) There is no fixed number
(b) Yes
(c) end of 2004-05 financial year.
(10) See answers to parts (1), (7) and (8).

(11) No. However, the Program is being opened to invite further proposals. Commercial broadcasters in the Northern Territory will be able to submit proposals to be considered with other proposals in this context.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 July 2003:

question.para: (1) Do individuals and organisations have to receive a security clearance through the Defence Security Authority (DSA) prior to those individuals and organisations being considered for a contract with or for employment with Defence.
(2) (a) When does the DSA commence the security clearance process; and
(b) does the DSA only commence the clearance process after a contract or employment has been secured with Defence.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) In relation to Australian Defence Force and Australian Public Service employment, selection is on the basis of the best person for the job. Following selection, the security clearance process commences, if applicable. In relation to the provision of external services, similar principles apply, that is selection on the basis of best value for money. However, an existing security clearance may be required where urgent operational requirements apply.
(2) (a) DSA commences the security clearance process when requested to do so by the relevant Defence sponsor, in line with corporate priorities.
(b) Not always. For example, where tender documentation is classified, preferred bidders may be security cleared in advance of the selection process.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Air Force: Woomera Detention Centre
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1611)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 July 2003:

question.para: With reference to training exercises or other flights made by the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF):
(1) Why were flights made over the Woomera detention centre during 1999-2002.
(2) How many flights were made over the centre.
(3) For each flight over the centre, what was: (a) the minimum altitude of the aircraft; and (b) the type of aircraft.
(4) Are any other detention centres under the flight paths of RAAF aircraft in routine, training or occasional flight; if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Woomera airfield is used primarily for weapons preparation and trials, Army training and pilot training. The Woomera detention centre is located three kilometres south of the Woomera airfield, directly under the extended centreline for the main runway which is aligned north/south. As such, any aircraft approaching Woomera airfield from the south or taking off towards the South will unavoidably pass over, or very close to, the Woomera detention centre.

(2) An extensive examination of Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) records, has identified at least 560 flights into or out of Woomera during the period 1999-2002. These records do not indicate the number of flights that overflew the detention centre.
(3) (a) RAAF records do not contain information on altitudes of overflying aircraft.

(b) Types of aircraft that have conducted operations at Woomera during the period are F/A-18 Hornet, C-130 Hercules, P3 Orion, B200 Super Kingair, PC9, S70A Blackhawk, UH1H Iroquois, BAe 748, Falcon 900 and Boeing 737. Royal Air Force Tornado aircraft also operated from Woomera during August 2000.

(4) RAAF aircraft may overfly other detention centres while following Air Traffic Control instructions during departure from or approach to a number of airfields or while en-route. In particular, the contingency facility at HMAS Coonawarra in Darwin is close to Darwin airfield and would likely be overflown by some aircraft approaching or departing Darwin. In addition, the facility at Singleton could be overflown by aircraft operating in the Singleton Range training airspace.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 July 2003:

question.para: With reference to the April 2003 `Handbook of Military Medical Operations Medical Management of Radiological Casualties' produced by the United States (US) Armed Forces Radiobiology Research Institute and, in particular, pages 59 and 60 relating to depleted uranium (DU):
(1) Was the Government made aware of this handbook and its instructions prior to sending Australian troops to Iraq.
(2) Did the Government request advice from the US Administration prior to deployment with regard to DU exposure; if so, can details of these requests be provided; if not, why not.
(3) Is there an equivalent Australian Defence Force handbook dealing with DU exposure; if not, why not; if so, can a copy be provided.

(4) (a) Has the Government been informed of the likelihood of Australian troops or members of the Australian media having been exposed to DU; if not, when is this advice expected; and (b) what are the medical implications of waiting for this advice before conducting radiobioassay testing of troops.
(5) Were any Australian troops or media personnel provided with the `normally issued chemical protective masks' described in the US handbook; if so, how many and in what circumstances.
(6) What tests were done on military and other equipment returning to Australia from Iraq for DU contamination.
(7) Were Australian troops warned against souveniring DU munitions or fragments.
(8) What checks were made to ensure that such material was not brought back to Australia by troops.
(9) Have DU munitions or fragments now been removed from recent operations in Iraq; if not, what measures are in place to guard against Iraqi civilian contamination from souveniring such material.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) No. The handbook was not released until April 2003, which was after Australian troops had deployed.

(3) No. However, although not directly dealing with DU, the following publications are used by the Australian Defence Force (ADF) for the management of radiological casualties: Health Policy Directive 005 - Initial Medical Procedures for Radiation Accidents and Radioactive Contamination; ADFP 53 - Health Support, Chapter 9 - Health support in Nuclear, Biological and Chemical Environments; ADFP 15 - Nuclear, Biological and chemical Defence, Chapter 8 - Medical Support; and ADFP 724 - Ionising Radiation Safety Manual. A draft health bulletin on DU Screening is currently being staffed.

(4) (a) Yes. The Australian Gulf War Veterans' Health Study 2003 was published and presented to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in February 2003 and the possibility of DU exposure is raised within this three volume document. The threat of DU exposure has also been raised in two Senate Legislative Committee Briefs by Directorate Health Services Branch: Gulf War Syndrome - 21 Nov 02 and 2nd Gulf War Health Issues Jun 03.
(b) None.

(5) No. All ADF personnel deployed to the Middle East Area of Operations were individually issued the UK designed S10 standard personnel protective equipment mask. Media personnel were responsible for their own protective equipment and were not issued any equipment by the ADF.

(6) In accordance with Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS) input to the current developing doctrine Australian Army Land Warfare Procedures (General) LWP-G 4-0-4 Cleaning and Inspection Procedures Military Equipment and Personnel Returning to Australia, all vehicles, equipment and personnel packs were stripped down, cleaned, packed in plastic and wiped down again prior to loading and return to Australia. These procedures meet all the requirements of AQIS import conditions that require no specific tests with regards to DU.

(7) No. Australian troops were reminded of their obligations by law with regard to souveniring, in accordance with Defence Instruction (General) Operations 32-1 `Appropriation and import of Defence related materiel during Australian Defence Force operations', but DU munitions or fragments were not specifically briefed.
(8) The belongings of all troops were subject to AQIS inspections but their belongings were not specifically checked for DU contamination.

(9) Coalition partners who used DU munitions in Iraq are responsible for the management of residual ordnance containing DU. The decision to conduct assessments of the effects of depleted uranium (DU) used in the Gulf War is a matter for the United States administration and the World Health Organisation, in consultation with the Iraqi Interim Authority and a future Iraqi Government.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 July 2003:

question.para: With reference to a memorandum forwarded to the Minister's office from the United States Deputy Chief of Staff for Operations and Plans, dated August 1993, which directs the Secretary of the Army to: (a) provide adequate training for personnel who may come into contact with depleted uranium (DU) contaminated equipment; (b) complete medical testing for personnel exposed to DU contamination during the Persian Gulf War; and (c) develop a plan for DU contaminated equipment recovery during future operations: Was the Government aware of any similar directives being made in advance of or during the attack on Iraq.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 July 2003:

question.para: With reference to US Army Regulation 40-5 which, in 1998, said `bioassay procedures will be performed when radioactive materials are used in such a manner that they could be inhaled, ingested, or absorbed into the body' and that personnel potentially exposed to ionizing radiation or non-ionizing radiation would receive medical examinations:
(1) Is the Government aware of any bioassay procedures being performed on United States (US) or Australian troops who may have inhaled, ingested or absorbed into the body radioactive materials.
(2) Is the Government aware of any radiation protection officers being sent to Iraq by the US Administration.
(3) Did the Government provide such personnel for Australian troops.
(4) Have US forces used weapons containing depleted uranium during training exercises in Australia; if so, when and where.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Defence Force (ADF) is aware that the United States (US) has collected some urine samples for analysis (bioassay) and that the US expects to collect additional samples as soldiers return from Iraq. The ADF is also aware that the US has recently updated its policy for the medical assessment of individuals potentially exposed to depleted uranium during operations in Iraq. Recent scientific studies suggest that there may be a slight risk associated with significant ingestion and inhalation of DU. Consequently, as a precautionary measure under our duty of care to ADF personnel, Defence Health Services is currently developing its own testing protocols for ADF personnel who may have been exposed to depleted uranium. Those members who may have been exposed to DU will have urine and blood tests done to check for adverse effects on kidney and blood forming systems.
(2) Yes. The US has deployed nuclear military health physicists and radiation protection officers to Iraq as part of Operation Iraqi Freedom.
(3) No. Coalition officers are available to perform radiation protection services if required.

(4) In accordance with Defence Instruction (General) Administration 59-1, specific approval must be sought by foreign forces to use any munitions other than exists in the ADF inventory on Australian Training Areas. The ADF does not have in service any ammunition containing DU. The ADF and its contractors have reviewed documents and data pertaining to the weapons used on Australian Training Areas and any requests from foreign forces for the use of DU munitions. No evidence of DU ammunition being used on Australian Training Areas was found.
